title: 2 Men Convicted of Killing Malcolm X Will Be Exonerated After Decades
abstract: The 1966 convictions of the two men are expected to be thrown out after a lengthy investigation, validating long-held doubts about who killed the civil rights leader.
byline: By Ashley Southall and Jonah E. Bromwich

title: As G.O.P. Fights Mask and Vaccine Mandates, Florida Takes the Lead
abstract: Florida lawmakers, at the request of Gov. Ron DeSantis, passed new laws sharply curtailing mask and vaccine mandates. Fringe anti-vaccination views met with little pushback.

multimedia.caption: Hundreds of anti-mandate protesters rallied outside the Florida Capitol this week.

title: White House Plans Major Expansion of Covid Vaccine Production
abstract: The Biden administration will spend billions of dollars on a new plan to combat the pandemic, investing in antiviral pills, rapid tests and manufacturing.

multimedia.caption: Activists have been demanding for months that Mr. Biden do more to scale up global vaccine manufacturing capacity.
multimedia.copyright: Mike Kai Chen for The New York Times

title: Overdose Deaths Reached Record High as the Pandemic Spread
abstract: More than 100,000 Americans died from drug overdoses in the yearlong period ending in April, government researchers said.

multimedia.caption: Paramedics in Brooklyn, Md., responded to a patient in cardiac arrest after an overdose in May 2020.

title: House, Mostly Along Party Lines, Censures Gosar for Violent Video
abstract: The Arizona Republican is the first member of the House to be formally rebuked in more than a decade. He was also removed from two committees.
byline: By Jonathan Weisman and Catie Edmondson

multimedia.caption: The House voted to censure Representative Paul Gosar, Republican of Arizona, and strip him of his seats on the Oversight and Natural Resources Committees.
multimedia.copyright: Al Drago for The New York Times

title: Jan. 6 Defendant Known as QAnon Shaman Sentenced to 41 Months
abstract: Jacob Chansley, who wore a horned helmet and a fur pelt as he stormed onto the Senate floor during the Capitol riot, had earlier pleaded guilty to a single felony count.

multimedia.caption: Jacob Chansley, a former actor and Navy sailor, was one of the first rioters to break into the Capitol on Jan. 6.

title: Catholic Bishops Avoid Confrontation With Biden Over Communion
abstract: In a vote, they endorsed new guidance on offering holy communion to public figures but did not overtly mention the president or other officials who support abortion rights.
org_facet: United States Conference of Catholic Bishops

multimedia.caption: This week’s meeting in Baltimore is the first in-person general assembly of the United States Conference of Catholic Bishops since 2019.

title: Rittenhouse Jurors Head Home for Second Night With No Verdict
abstract: Kyle Rittenhouse’s defense team sought a mistrial on Wednesday, its second such request. The judge has yet to rule on either.
byline: By Julie Bosman and Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs

multimedia.caption: Demonstrators could be heard from inside the Kenosha County Courthouse on Wednesday, when several dozen protesters lingered on the courthouse steps.
multimedia.copyright: Carlos Javier Ortiz for The New York Times

title: Risk for Leader of Belarus: Migrants He Lured May Want to Stay
abstract: President Aleksandr G. Lukashenko of Belarus, whom the E.U. accuses of engineering a migrant crisis on the border with Poland, could face a serious headache if asylum seekers try to stay in his country.

multimedia.caption: Migrants in Belarus on the border with Poland, which has been girded with razor wire, on Wednesday.
multimedia.copyright: James Hill for The New York Times

title: A Green Light at the Window for Migrants
abstract: An unofficial network of local residents, activists and volunteer medics in Poland has been working to support those who have made it across from Belarus in freezing conditions.

multimedia.caption: Maria Ancipuk, a resident of Michalowo, Poland, has placed a green light in a window to show migrants that her home is a safe place to ask for help.
multimedia.copyright: Maciek Nabrdalik for The New York Times

title: How the Belarus Standoff Is Unlike Recent Migrant Crises
abstract: The images at the Belarus-Poland border look familiar, but this emergency has little in common with previous waves of people from Syria, Myanmar and Afghanistan.
des_facet: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

multimedia.caption: Migrants camping on the Belarusian side of the border on Tuesday night.
multimedia.copyright: James Hill for The New York Times

title: What Apple’s New Repair Program Means for You (and Your iPhone)
abstract: Apple said it would soon provide parts, tools and manuals to those who wanted to fix their own iPhones and Mac computers.

multimedia.caption: Apple said Wednesday that it will introduce a program early next year for customers who are comfortable doing their own repairs on Apple products.

title: To Honor His Indigenous Ancestors, He Became a Champion
abstract: Inspired by his great-grandfather’s repeated escapes from an Indigenous boarding school, Ku Stevens, 18, retraced the route. Then he set his sights on winning a Nevada state title.
org_facet: Stewart Indian School Cultural Center and Museum

multimedia.caption: “When I run, I take my history with me and especially Frank Quinn,” said Ku Stevens, referring to his great-grandfather, who escaped the Stewart Indian School by running 50 miles back to his reservation.
multimedia.copyright: Sharon Chischilly for The New York Times

title: Adele Has a Lot of Big Feelings on ‘30’
abstract: The British superstar’s first album in six years deals with divorce and moving on, countering misery with virtuosity.

multimedia.caption: Adele’s voice — cooing, declaiming, arguing, teasing, imploring, quivering, breaking, shouting — is rightfully at the center of “30.”

title: One Chaste Marriage, Four Kids, and the Catholic Church
abstract: A son reflects on his parents’ commitment, endorsed by the Catholic Church, to cohabit chastely like “brother and sister” to avoid mortal sin.

title: The Truth About Kyle Rittenhouse’s Gun
abstract: Kyle Rittenhouse’s semiautomatic rifle endangered everybody around him —  and himself.

multimedia.caption: The lead prosecutor in the Kyle Rittenhouse trial,  Thomas Binger, with the gun Mr. Rittenhouse used to shoot three people.

title: The Supply-Chain Crisis Is a Labor Crisis
abstract: Governments around the world have failed transport workers. But it’s not too late to help them.

title: White Men on Trial
abstract: Race hangs heavy over cases featuring white male defendants accused of everything from murder to insurrection.

multimedia.caption: Travis McMichael is one of three white men accused of killing Ahmaud Arbery.

title: Democrats Shouldn’t Panic. They Should Go Into Shock.
abstract: “No administration is going to thrive in that economic environment.”

multimedia.caption: Disappointed supporters of Terry McAuliffe, who lost the governor’s race in Virginia to Glenn Youngkin, a Republican. It may be a while before Democrats have much to cheer about.

title: I’m 87, Triple Vaxxed and Living My Life Again
abstract: My life expectancy is six more years. Covid-19 can’t prevent me from enjoying the time I have left.

multimedia.copyright: Matthew Monteith for The New York Times

title: Can Covid Winter Be Merry and Bright? We Asked the Experts.
abstract: Three experts respond to questions from readers about how to navigate another Covid winter.
byline: By The New York Times Opinion

title: What if Your Kids Never Let You Sleep Again?
abstract: You can’t control your children’s sleep. And you probably don’t have to.

title: What We See in the Shameful Trends on U.S. Maternal Health
abstract: Especially for women of color.
byline: By Sema K. Sgaier and Jordan Downey

title: When I Unplugged, I Connected With the Truth.
abstract: I found a great liberation in playing folk music on an acoustic guitar.

title: The Pandemic Prompted People to Retire Early. Will They Return to Work?
abstract: Workers who retired because of Covid-19 are being enticed to return.

multimedia.copyright: The New York Times; Photographs by Carlos. E. Serrano, OliverChilds and amnachphoto via Getty Images

title: Bosnia Is On the Brink of Breaking Up
abstract: This is what happened when the West looked away from my country.

multimedia.caption: Milorad Dodik

title: ‘Woke’ Went the Way of ‘P.C.’ and ‘Liberal’
abstract: Progressives can still fall back on “progressive.”

title: Why Identity Politics Isn’t Working for Asian Americans
abstract: Two Asian Americans question the term and its value.

multimedia.copyright: Photographs by Evan Groll and Sarah Shatz

title: Alan Cumming Talks About ‘Baggage’
abstract: The actor and author discusses his new memoir, and Allen C. Guelzo talks about “Robert E. Lee: A Life.”
des_facet: Baggage: Tales From a Fully Packed Life (Book)

title: The Emotional and Financial Business of Taylor Swift’s ‘All Too Well’
abstract: What does the rerecorded song from “Red” say about how power and the past have shaped her career?

title: The 10 Best Books of 2021: A Virtual Event Announcing Our List
abstract: On Nov. 30, Times subscribers will be the first to find out what made this year’s 10 Best Books list from editors of The Book Review and a guest, Lena Waithe.

title: Jason Mott Wins National Book Award for ‘Hell of a Book’
abstract: Tiya Miles won the nonfiction prize for “All That She Carried.” The author Karen Tei Yamashita received a lifetime achievement award.

multimedia.caption: Jason Mott won the National Book Award for fiction for “Hell of a Book.”

title: Man Who Fatally Shot Ahmaud Arbery Describes a ‘Life or Death’ Encounter
abstract: Travis McMichael, who has pleaded not guilty to murder charges, took the stand in his own defense on Wednesday.

multimedia.caption: Travis McMichael testified Wednesday during his murder trial in Glynn County, Ga.
multimedia.copyright: Pool photo by Stephen B. Morton-Pool

title: Young Dolph, Promising Memphis Rapper, Shot and Killed at 36
abstract: Known for collaborating widely and his deadpan bravado, his last solo album, “Rich Slave,” debuted at No. 4 on the Billboard chart last year.
byline: By Jon Caramanica and Joe Coscarelli

multimedia.caption: All of Young Dolph’s last six albums (solo and collaborative) debuted in the Top 25 on the Billboard chart.

title: Cy Young Awards Go to Pitchers Who Never Stopped Believing
abstract: Milwaukee’s Corbin Burnes and Toronto’s Robbie Ray had hit rock bottom before they worked their way up to stardom.

multimedia.caption: Corbin Burnes of the Milwaukee Brewers and Robbie Ray of the Toronto Blue Jays struggled in recent seasons, but they were the top pitchers for 2021.
multimedia.copyright: Ashley Landis/Associated Press; Adrian Kraus/Associated Press/Associated Press

title: Striking Deere workers approve a new contract on the third try.
abstract: The accord, after a five-week walkout by 10,000 employees, increases wages and performance-based pay.

multimedia.caption: Members of the United Auto Workers on strike last month outside a John Deere plant in Ankeny, Iowa.

title: Black Man Stomped by South Carolina Officer Will Receive $650,000 Settlement
abstract: When the man did not lie on the ground quickly, because he has metal rods and pins in his leg and hip, a police officer stomped on the back of his head.

multimedia.caption: At a news conference in August, Clarence Gailyard, center, watched police body camera video of an officer stomping on him. At left is his lawyer, Justin Bamberg.

title: C.D.C. Investigates Flu Outbreak at University of Michigan
abstract: There have been 528 cases of the flu on the university’s campus in Ann Arbor, a vast majority in students who have not had flu shots, school officials said.
org_facet: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

multimedia.caption: The University of Michigan campus in Ann Arbor on Tuesday.
multimedia.copyright: Ryan Garza/Detroit Free Press, via USA Today Network

title: N.C.A.A. Expands Division I Women’s Basketball Tournament
abstract: Beginning with the competition in March 2022, the women’s bracket will include 68 teams, up from 64, as the N.C.A.A. continues to try to rectify gender disparities.

multimedia.caption: No. 7 Stanford, the defending national champion, has started the season 2-1, with its loss coming to a ranked Texas team.

title: Intractable African Crises Flare as Biden’s Top Diplomat Visits Kenya
abstract: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken hoped to ease the turmoil engulfing Sudan and Ethiopia in his first trip to sub-Saharan Africa. Both worsened on his first full day.
byline: By Michael Crowley and Declan Walsh

multimedia.caption: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken speaking in Nairobi, Kenya, on Wednesday.

title: Boris Johnson Battered in Parliament as Scandal Puts Him on Defense
abstract: Reversals and broken promises have eroded his party’s lead in the polls, and the prime minister faces a low-grade mutiny from Conservatives angry over a proposal to limit their options for extra income.
byline: By Mark Landler and Stephen Castle

multimedia.caption: Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain faces a furor over Conservative Party lawmakers taking lucrative outside work.

title: Script Supervisor Sues Alec Baldwin and Others in ‘Rust’ Shooting
abstract: A lawsuit filed by the supervisor, Mamie Mitchell, said an injury or death on the set was “a likely result” of the production’s failure to follow safety protocols.
byline: By Julia Jacobs and Graham Bowley

multimedia.caption: A second lawsuit was filed in the fatal shooting of a cinematographer on the set of the Alec Baldwin film “Rust.”

title: Greece to Put Aid Workers Who Helped Migrants on Trial on Espionage Charges
abstract: The country’s conservative government is toughening its stance on migration and on groups working with migrants, aligning itself with a hardening climate across Europe.
des_facet: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

multimedia.caption: Volunteers directing a raft of migrants off the Greek island of Lesbos in 2016.
multimedia.copyright: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times

title: What Should We Do With Robert Smithson and Nancy Holt’s Island?
abstract: In the 1970s, the artists bought a rocky strip of land off the coast of Maine. Now, it’s a place for others to wrestle with their legacies.

multimedia.caption: Little Fort Island this past June.

title: Neal Stephenson’s Mad, Mad, Mad, Mad World
abstract: “Termination Shock,” his latest novel, is set in a future gone haywire from the impacts of climate disaster.

title: The Untold Story of Von Dutch
abstract: Behind the brand that made trucker hats hot in the early 2000s is a messy corporate origin tale, filled with sabotage and greed.
des_facet: The Curse of Von Dutch: A Brand to Die For (TV Program)

multimedia.caption: Von Dutch, the brand best known for making logo-emblazoned trucker hats cool in the aughts, is the subject of a new Hulu documentary.

title: 1,200 Miles From Kabul, a Celebrated Music School Reunites
abstract: Students and teachers of the Afghanistan National Institute of Music and their families, almost 200 in the past week, have fled to Qatar to escape Taliban restrictions on music.

multimedia.caption: Ahmad Naser Sarmast hugging two students from the Afghanistan National Institute of Music, which he leads. Students and their families, along with instructors, fled to Qatar where they will be free to play music.

title: The Best Movies on Amazon Prime Video Right Now
abstract: New films, and classics, just keep coming, but you don’t have to drill down to find the finest selections to stream. We’ll do the heavy lifting. You press play.

multimedia.caption: Colin Firth in a scene from “A Single Man.”

title: My Pandemic Cat Had a Secret
abstract: First of all, she wasn’t a kitten …

title: How Do You Manage the Holidays After Hardship?
abstract: The Times wants to hear from you.

title: I Never Expected to Love Full-Time Motherhood
abstract: A queer woman who once shunned tradition discovers domestic calm in uncertain times.

multimedia.caption: During the pandemic, Stephanie Fairyington has embraced being a full-time parent to her daughter, Marty, 4.
multimedia.copyright: Josefina Santos for The New York Times

title: The ‘Sex Talk’ Is Actually a Series of Talks
abstract: Several psychologists and sexual health experts offer ways to make conversations about sex informative and comfortable for children and parents.

title: All Babies Cry, but How Much Is Too Much?
abstract: Babies with colic can be incredibly challenging, but thankfully the condition ends on its own.
